title: Sentiment Survey
summary:
# Comprehensive Review on Sentiment Analysis: Tasks, Approaches, and Applications

This survey paper by Kumar et al. provides a thorough examination of sentiment analysis (SA), an emerging field in text mining that computationally identifies and categorizes opinions expressed in text across social media platforms. The paper addresses the growing importance of understanding customer sentiment toward products, services, and market trends as organizations increasingly depend on user feedback to improve their offerings.

## Core Concepts and Classification Levels

Sentiment analysis, also known as opinion mining, operates at three distinct levels: document level, sentence level, and aspect level. Document-level SA treats an entire document as expressing a single positive or negative opinion about a product. Sentence-level classification, widely used in e-commerce, categorizes each sentence into positive, negative, or neutral opinions. Aspect-level analysis, also called feature-based analysis, breaks down reviews into specific aspects and their associated sentiments, providing deeper insights into what users liked or disliked.

The field integrates multiple NLP tasks including named entity recognition, concept extraction, sarcasm detection, aspect extraction, and subjectivity detection. Subjective texts express opinions while objective texts present factual information, and distinguishing between them is fundamental to SA.

## Methodological Approaches

The paper divides sentiment classification techniques into two main categories: lexicon-based approaches and machine learning approaches. Lexicon-based methods use dictionaries of words annotated with semantic orientation, further divided into dictionary-based and corpus-based approaches. Machine learning approaches include supervised, unsupervised, and semi-supervised learning techniques.

Supervised learning relies on annotated datasets to build prediction models, with early work achieving 81.5% accuracy on probabilistic classifiers. The BERT model represents a significant advancement, using bidirectional training to understand language context more deeply. Unsupervised approaches, such as cluster analysis, find hidden patterns without labeled data. Popular lexicon tools include VADER, SentiStrength, and General Inquirer.

Word embedding techniques like word2vec and GloVe have become dominant in NLP, addressing the computational inefficiencies of one-hot encoding by mapping words with similar meanings to similar vector representations.

## Multimodal Sentiment Analysis

Beyond text, SA extends to speech, images, and video. Speech-based sentiment analysis extracts emotional cues from spoken utterances, with pitch-related features proving particularly informative. Image-based SA analyzes sentiments conveyed through visual content like memes and cartoons. Multimodal SA combines text, audio, and visual data, with Poria et al. achieving over 20% improvement over state-of-the-art methods using feature-based fusion techniques.

## Applications Across Domains

The applications of sentiment analysis span diverse fields. E-commerce platforms use SA to automate customer feedback analysis and rating prediction. Business intelligence leverages sentiment data to understand customer preferences and competitive positioning. Financial markets analyze Federal Open Market Committee statements to understand market sentiment. Smart home technologies adapt environments based on user emotions detected through voice assistants like Alexa and Google Home. Additional applications include hate speech detection on social media, suicide note analysis for mental health intervention, and stress detection from user-generated content.

## Challenges and Future Directions

Several challenges persist in sentiment analysis. Recognizing subjective parts of phrases remains difficult due to homonyms and context-dependent meanings. Domain dependence creates issues where the same word carries different sentiments in different contexts. Sarcasm detection poses significant difficulty since sarcastic sentences use positive words to express negative opinions. Word order matters critically, as phrases like "A is better than B" convey opposite meanings from "B is better than A." Multilingual analysis presents additional complexity, particularly for mixed languages like Hinglish combining Hindi and English.

The research shows increasing publication volume from 2011 to 2020, reflecting growing interest as industry evolves through 4.0 and into 5.0. Future work may combine sentiment analysis with network traffic analysis to detect fake opinions or news that can incite social unrest.

The paper references numerous datasets including IMDB Movie Reviews, Twitter data, Amazon Product Reviews, and multilingual corpora for Arabic, Chinese, Hindi, and Urdu. Popular tools mentioned include NLTK for text processing and OpenCV for computer vision tasks.
